data.body: I think we should not start adding controls to the core. Otherwise users will request to also include `TransformControls`, `TrackballControls` etc...

Why not?

I just started using this library yesterday, went through the getting started guide and ended up on the [Import via modules](https://threejs.org/docs/#manual/en/introduction/Import-via-modules) page which tells me why I shouldn't be script tags. 

I set up my webpack dev server and started hacking away, and one of the first things I wanted to do was move my cube around with the mouse. I found the [OrbitControls](https://threejs.org/docs/#examples/controls/OrbitControls)  page and tried to import it, but my typescript compiler threw an error telling me "three has no module OrbitControls". I googled around and found some custom implementations, some people said use the three-orbitcontrols-ts module, and others said do this:

```javascript
import * as THREE from 'three';
import 'three/examples/js/controls/OrbitControls';
```

That imports the whole three library and makes a huge bundle, which isn't very efficient, and isn't great for production. I'd much rather do the intuitive thing and just import the controls and use them, why wouldn't they be included in the core?

> Why not?

If anything, we should be trying to move things out of the core, not add more. 

In any case, this issue will become moot once #9562 is (finally!) resolved. 
It's a very long issue but if you want understand while files in the /examples folder are not yet modules then have a read through that to see some of the problems that have been encountered, and possible solutions.

I removed all references to the global THREE variable in this port, everything that was being referenced from THREE was already available in the /src folder so I just imported everything I needed. Technically there shouldn't be anything wrong with this PR, it won't affect the existing examples folder or the global THREE variable. Other than that, what issue is there with adding this? 

I didn't read all the comments (looks like 2 years of [bikeshedding](http://bikeshed.com/) with no decisions on how to actually move forward) but what I did gather from those comments is a ton of people would like to use orbit controls this way.

You have both mentioned the core, and why things shouldn't be added to it, but what's the alternative? as far as I know something can only be a core if other things are peripheral to it, but there is only one three repo that I'm aware of. Why even have a documentation page on OrbitControls if it doesn't belong in the library?

> looks like 2 years of bikeshedding

Unfortunately yes, to some degree. A lot of people have strong and often conflicting opinions on how to proceed with this and that makes it hard to reach any consensus. 

However there is also #14803, which hopefully marks a path forward.

The controls were moved to the examples 6 years ago. See https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/commit/04b652ae26e228796f67838c0ec4d555e8b16528 for why.

Whether to promote `OrbitControls` to the library is up to @mrdoob.

@mikemeerschaert For future reference, please see [How to Contribute to three.js](https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/wiki/How-to-contribute-to-three.js) -- especially the last two bullet points. Avoid tab-to-space conversion.

Ok @WestLangley thanks. I think the scope of this pr should just be getting this one module into the library to make the module imports consistent with the documentation. And thanks for the note, I'll fix the formatting when I get home from work. I use prettier and I'll adjust the settings to conform to the style guide.
On whether OrbitControls should be in the core library or not, though, I don't think I have an opinion.

> Can you still import it without importing the entire library?

See https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/pull/14803#issuecomment-417099084. That is definitely a requirement I think, so if the PR  isn’t working that way already we’ll need to resolve that before merging the PR.

> ... you now have a syntax that requires knowledge of the whole libraries file structure ...

Keep in mind that we cannot put everything from `examples/js` into the core library, so `import { RarelyUsedLoader } from ‘three’;` isn’t an option. With that constraint, do you have suggestions for how to make it better? We could, for example, include the “how to import this file” at the top of the documentation for every file that isn’t part of the core library.

It's obviously up to @mrdoob, but if I were to offer a suggestion I'd say have a readme that tells people that if they want a module from the examples library they should put in a feature request for it, and if it gets enough +1's it should be ported over to the core library and have the the THREE references refactored to use existing exported modules. If the dependant THREE properties haven't been ported yet, they should get moved over as well.

I don't know what the issue is with having a lot of stuff in the core library as long as it's well documented (I've found the documentation on this library to be pretty outstang considering it's complexity!). And as long as you aren't doing `import * as THREE from 'three'` your bundle size won't be affected by the additional modules.
@mikemeerschaert As I pointed out, `OrbitControls` is not part of the core because users want to modify `OrbitControls`.

The goal right now is to ensure things that aren't in the core library (for whatever reason) are still as easy as possible to include in your project.

Not everyone has tree-shaking available, or uses ES modules yet, or even necessarily uses a build system. I'm not sure what the bar should be for a file to be added to the core library, but I think it does need to be more than just popularity. Files that other example modules depend on are better candidates. Having additional threejs NPM modules someday (think `import { OrbitControls } from '@three/controls'`) would be interesting in the future, but we need to get things ported to ES modules before considering that.

> It seems like the easiest thing is just to port them all to the core library on request.

Unfortunately that's not an acceptable general solution... I think you're describing a discovery and documentation problem, for which adding files to the core library is only one of many technical solutions. There will always be a need for plugins to exist, as in many other libraries, and we need to get to the point where those external plugins are clearly documented and easily-importable (which I admit they aren't now).

**EDIT:** That said, I have no problem with requests for specific files to be added to the core library, like this one. There are many reasons we should consider additions from time to time. But I don't know if OrbitControls qualifies, @mrdoob can make that decision.

> There are many reasons we should consider additions from time to time.

`GLTFLoader` is one candidate from my point of view.

I think this issue should be closed for three reasons:

1. We have consensus that examples should be modularized and that already includes OrbitControls. Therefore this issue is redundant with infamous bikeshedding discussion.

2. Once examples are modularized, it does not matter what is in core/build because it will be extremely easy to make custom bundles with modules from examples included.

3. In the future, it will not matter what is bundled in the core/build since the practice of bundling is slowly but surely becoming unnecessary.

Sorry for making another big bikeshedding argument on this simple pr, you guys seem to have a direction you want to go with the library and you've put a lot of work into it, and I've only been using it for a couple of days.

That being said, @sanonz, if you do that, you import the entire library and the whole thing ends up in your bundle. Furthermore, it gets duplicated if you import other things from core elsewhere in your code. See  https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/pull/15070#issuecomment-430738375. Much better to refactor OrbitControls to remove references from THREE and instead import the dependencies from the 'three' library. I think weather you split three up into smaller modules or keep it all in core, you'd still want to refactor the modules in examples to remove the dependency on the global THREE object.

@sanonz I agree that would be very convenient, but I'd vote to just keep focused on ES modules for now, which have to be solved first anyway... there are pros/cons to NPM packages, that can be discussed after ES modules are solved...

> Sorry for making another big bikeshedding argument ...

No problem @mikemeerschaert, it's a totally fair suggestion. :)

> ... you import the entire library and the whole thing ends up in your bundle. Furthermore, it gets duplicated if you import other things from core elsewhere in your code ... you'd still want to refactor the modules in examples to remove the dependency on the global THREE object.

Agreed, we have to solve that in any case. I think it's a prerequisite to using ES modules at all here.
@mrdoob Interesting -- is there a plan for the @threejs org? Will examples be moved into many separate repos? Or will there be a separate examples repo?
maybe you can see https://gist.github.com/cecilemuller/0be98dcbb0c7efff64762919ca486a59.
